text.p: These are the leading stories in the Lebanese press on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Prime Minister Hariri cancels planned trip to Paris, returns to Lebanon.
- Escalation of violence in south Lebanon between the resistance and Israeli-allied militia.
- Morocco's King Hassan informs Hariri his country will not attend the Doha Arab-Israeli economic conference.
The meeting has been held annually since 1994. But this year, many Arab countries are angry at what they see as Israeli stalling on the Middle East peace process.
- Israeli shelling of south Lebanon wounds one person and damages houses.
- Maronite council attacks the government's economic policies in a tough statement.

- The government will allow residents of the Bekaa valley to gather on Friday in response to former Hizbollah leader Sheikh Sobhi al-Tufaili's call for a "hunger revolt" against poverty in the region.
- Ministers from the current government will leave their jobs when a new government is formed.
- Prime Minister Hariri said after meeting his counterpart in Morocco that the Israeli occupation of southern Lebanon is the last obstacle to peace.
